title: IHS

content: You know, in may respects IHS represents violence in its origin. The Latin initials IHS is "In Hoc Signo (Vinces)" (By this Sign (Conquer)) and was adopted by the Roman Emperor Constantine for his legions when he converted to Christianity in the early 4th Century. As the story goes, prior to the battle with Maxentius near the Milvian Bridge at Rome, Constantine dreamed of a cross of light in the sky and the words "In hoc signo vinces." Thus, Constantine, being the superstitious man he was, had the cross (or Greek letters Chi and Rho) inscribed on his soldiers' shields. Constantine won the battle and converted the Empire to Christianity forceably. Much later the Jesuits (Society of Jesus), who were known for their violent ways of "converting" people to the true faith, probably had this story in mind when they incorporated an "IHS" inside a sun for their insignia. Of course the cross itself is a symbol of violence and punishment for those who rebel against the status quo. Many a Protestant reject the symbol as being "Papist" and some even refuse to acknowledge it because it was on the shields of Roman soldiers as they forced the masses into conversion to Christianity and then to punish the "wrong" kind of Christians who questioned the whole deal of the faith selling out to Caesar. It's not as clean and simple symbol as one might think. I can understand why an educated man like Obama might have his misgivings about it. He wouldn't be the first. So did some of the Reformers did likewise.

content: quote: Originally posted by reducetension: You know, in may respects IHS represents violence in its origin. The Latin initials IHS is "In Hoc Signo (Vinces)" (By this Sign (Conquer)) and was adopted by the Roman Emperor Constantine for his legions when he converted to Christianity in the early 4th Century. As the story goes, prior to the battle with Maxentius near the Milvian Bridge at Rome, Constantine dreamed of a cross of light in the sky and the words "In hoc signo vinces." Thus, Constantine, being the superstitious man he was, had the cross (or Greek letters Chi and Rho) inscribed on his soldiers' shields. Constantine won the battle and converted the Empire to Christianity forceably. Much later the Jesuits (Society of Jesus), who were known for their violent ways of "converting" people to the true faith, probably had this story in mind when they incorporated an "IHS" inside a sun for their insignia. Of course the cross itself is a symbol of violence and punishment for those who rebel against the status quo. Many a Protestant reject the symbol as being "Papist" and some even refuse to acknowledge it because it was on the shields of Roman soldiers as they forced the masses into conversion to Christianity and then to punish the "wrong" kind of Christians who questioned the whole deal of the faith selling out to Caesar. It's not as clean and simple symbol as one might think. I can understand why an educated man like Obama might have his misgivings about it. He wouldn't be the first. So did some of the Reformers did likewise. Deal w/ this Tense; not everyone believes Constantine was a Christian. The Pope at the time held much sway and he used his "conversion" for his political benefit as did the Catholic Church. So in truth both benefitted in this colusion and many people suffered and died. As usual you tell your reinvented historical version. Obama may be educated but it appears he is NO christian and may well be more comfortable as a Muslim. He is certainly a smooth talker but that does not make him a leader everyone would like to have. His education is as a point of contention for many people and his governing abilities are equally suspect. As to the Reformers, they were a more purist sort of beliver and made great strides to reset a course more in line with scripture. That ain't Nobama by any means bud! If you think so then you are spouting more of yo remanufactured truth as we know you have done before.(don't we). I missed a point with you. Christians are not superstitious as was the Con man.Pecalling that sc ripture that "satan can appear as an angel of light" may be an appropriate point to remember. Crosses are visible by looking at the sun in a number of circumstances so the story, true or not, would hold little if any sway with the reformers or me or oothers of Faith in Christ.

Obama may be educated but it appears he is NO christian and may well be more comfortable as a Muslim. He is certainly a smooth talker but that does not make him a leader everyone would like to have. His education is as a point of contention for many people and his governing abilities are equally suspect. As to the Reformers, they were a more purist sort of beliver and made great strides to reset a course more in line with scripture. That ain't Nobama by any means bud! If you think so then you are spouting more of yo remanufactured truth as we know you have done before.(don't we). I missed a point with you. Christians are not superstitious as was the Con man.Pecalling that sc ripture that "satan can appear as an angel of light" may be an appropriate point to remember. Crosses are visible by looking at the sun in a number of circumstances so the story, true or not, would hold little if any sway with the reformers or me or oothers of Faith in Christ.
